lines.speaker: notice
lines.text: You have entered Auckland, NZ.

lines.speaker: Mike
lines.text: See you folks on the flip side!

lines.speaker: Mike
lines.text: I'm going joyriding down in those mines.

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: thanks again, Mike!

lines.speaker: notice
lines.text: Mike descends back into the depths.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: huh. what's going on in the background?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: maybe we can take a closer look?

settings.beforeText: You hear faint music coming from within the data center.
settings.afterText: Strange, isn't it? And yet you were granted this recital, as if the data center knew you were already coming... a treasured memory.

settings.text: Looks like this might be the Auckland Data Centre from the outside. Smaller than you thought?

lines.speaker: Orb
lines.text: STOP. DESTINATION ADDRESS MUST BE PRESENTED BEFORE PASSAGE CAN BE GRANTED FOR ANY AND ALL SEAWARD JOURNIES.

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: *beeps*

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: uh, it's beeping again!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: WELCOME TO AUCKLAND!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: you need to stop scaring me like that!!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: If you're reading this, you're probably a packet who's just arrived in the wonderful City of Sails on your last stop before sailing internationally off across the Pacific. Please ensure you know your destination IP address before you depart!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: hey guide, now that we're in Auckland, can you show us to the nameserver?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Sure thing!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: is no one else weirded out by the fact that you talk?

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: Hey there, this is ns1.dnsblast.com! Heard you all were looking for [[redacted]]'s IP address?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: yeah!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: why *are* you the one that knows their IP address, anyway?

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: Oh, because [[redacted]] registered their domain through me!

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: Or, my parent company, anyway.

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: Every registrar has a number of nameservers that act as a phone book for all the domains registered through them. More than one, typically, to handle traffic when there's a lot of it. I'm ns1, but you better believe there's at *least* an ns2 and an ns3 as well.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: does that mean this is where [[redacted]] is hosted, too?

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: Usually not! In fact, their nameserver might not even be located in New Zealand.

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: I might just be an abstraction for the sake of your journey.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: *what*

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: But the company that hosts the actual *content* of the website and a site's domain registrar are often two different companies.

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: Even if the same company serves as both the host and the registrar, the nameservers of the company are still completely ignorant of the content.

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: I don't have the faintest clue of what's contained in [[redacted]]'s website. It could be nothing, though that seems unlikely!

lines.speaker: ns1
lines.text: All I can give you is an IP address, which is something like 14.1.88.255.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: That was a completely random IP address, that may or may not point to a real website, but it exists within the range of IP addresses for New Zealand! Did you know that you can look up the IP address range of any country? [Here's the full list of address blocks for New Zealand!](https://lite.ip2location.com/new-zealand-ip-address-ranges?lang=en_US) And if you [look up a domain name through ICANN](https://lookup.icann.org/), you can find out what its nameservers are!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: so now that we have the IP address, we're good? we can head the website?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I doubt it's that simple, but we can at least leave Auckland I think.

lines.speaker: notice
lines.text: Subject: Traceroutes and Hops

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: so we started at Wellington, then went to Whanganui, and now we're in Auckland.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: how does that work vis-a-vis the fact that this is a packet moving through the internet?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I can answer this one!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: there's the obvious part – any packet has to pass from router to router to router until it gets to its destination.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: if you send a packet to a server that's close to you geographically, it travels less physical distance and passes through fewer routers in the process.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: it's impossible to predict 100% where a packet will pass through, because if traffic is heavy in one location, a packet will get pushed elsewhere, even if geographically it seems like it makes less sense.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: but there are ways to get some idea of where it *might* go!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: `traceroute` is a terminal command that simulates the path by sending a bunch of packets with a really short Time-to-Live. each router we hear from is called a **hop** on the route.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Below is a graphical representation of this process!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: the first one has a TTL of 1, so it dies at the first hop.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: the next one has a TTL of 2, so it ought to make it back to the first hop, go forward one more hop, and die at that second router.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: if or when we get a packet that makes it all the way to the destination address, we know what routers we can expect most packets to pass through, and where those routers are.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: so when we tested this, were we endlessly sending your severed head over the wires, knowing it was destined only to die every time?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: that's a bit... morbid

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I'm not hearing a "no?"

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: anyways! sometimes, when we did a traceroute, it took us across the Pacific––other times, it seemed to go through Singapore and take us all the way across the world in the other direction!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: we're just basing the hops on our trip off of what seemed to be the most common.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: which involves going underwater, like we're about to do.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: If you've received your destination IP address and are satisfied with the knowledge you've gained thus far, it's time to dive!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Here in Auckland, packets are routed to the proper deep sea cable according to their final destinations and local traffic conditions.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Whatever cable you take, you're sure to be sailing the seven seas in luxury with our fantastic fleet of tar-soaked nylon yarn fibre optic cables!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yummy!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Featuring galvanized armor wires, a nylon yarn bedding, polyethelene insulation and a copper sheath, our fantastic fibre optic cables are securely wrapped in silicon gel and ultra-high strength steel wires for a deep sea cable experience you're sure not to forget.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: gosh, I wonder how much of this stuff there is in the ocean just to make the internet work...

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: An absolutely enormous amount of the world's internet infrastructure is made up of these underwater cables, as of 2021 there were more than 1.3 million kilometers of cable (and that's just of the cables currently in use).

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: wow, well let's hope your head doesn't get lost!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: See the map in the attached handout for further information.

lines.speaker: notice
lines.text: You receive the Submarine Cable Map.

settings.text: check out the global submarine cable map!

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: you're not kidding!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: that is an *extraordinary* amount of spaghetti!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: is it me, or does the Auckland cable only lead elsewhere in New Zealand?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I think you're right

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: how are we getting overseas, then?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: You'll see when you get to the coast!

settings.beforeText: You find the source of the music again. Just one more listen, you say to yourself.
settings.afterText: Do you feel that you have changed somehow? Perhaps you are smarter or more beautiful? Or is there some wisdom here? Rate this experience.
